values.alignmentText: National parks and coastal trails are easy to reach, yet dense metros mean weekend nature breaks require travel planning.
Hotter summers, stronger typhoons, and sea-level rise around Busan raise adaptation stakes.
Humid monsoon summers and below-freezing winters clash with the family’s mild-weather wish list.
Spring yellow dust and winter coal emissions push PM2.5 well above WHO guidance several times a year.
Typhoons, flash floods, and the remote risk of DPRK escalation require contingency plans despite strong preparedness.
10–20°C (50–68°F) with yellow dust and cherry blossoms.
July–August highs reach 30–33°C (86–91°F) with heavy humidity and tropical nights.
10–22°C (50–72°F) dry and clear.
Winter lows dip to -7°C (19°F) in Seoul, with dry winds that limit playground time.
Busan and Jeju offer beaches but not year-round swimming.
Summer waters near 24°C (75°F) cool by fall.
National parks, islands, and seasonal blossoms are scenic.
The 2024 minimum wage is ₩9,860/hour (~$7.40), supporting service workers but still tight in Seoul.
Senior engineers earn ₩70–100M ($55–78k), with bonuses in major studios and fintech firms.
Finance, telecom, and public agencies run .NET stacks, though many roles expect Korean fluency and office time.
Ruby is niche beyond startups like Coupang or Woowa Brothers, so openings are sporadic.
Large companies sponsor E-7 visas, but documentation and points-based reviews can slow onboarding.
A resilient export economy with strong R&D keeps unemployment low despite global slowdowns.
Hybrid schedules are growing, yet many teams still value in-office collaboration.
The 52-hour cap exists, but presenteeism and late client calls remain common in tech.
Official weeks are 40 hours, yet unpaid overtime or weekend sprints surface near launches.
Annual leave starts around 15 days after the first year, backed by national holidays.
Many employees leave days unused due to workload and cultural pressure.
Seoul moves fast with crowded commutes; coastal cities like Busan feel marginally slower.
Schools run 8:30–15:00, but cram schools extend evenings, and parents often sync late office hours.
Families split weekends between kid activities, markets, and short rail trips to national parks.
Strong family emphasis but work hours limit together time.
Non-monogamy has little social or legal acceptance.
High academic expectations and structured extracurriculars.
Safe with many kid cafes and parks yet space is limited.
Public schools high-performing but intense; international schools costly.
Government expanding daycare though spots in Seoul fill quickly.
Monthly subsidies and free preschool for ages 3–5.
Foreign residents can access some subsidies but coverage varies.
Universal and high quality with strong outcomes.
Public schools open to foreigners though Korean fluency is expected.
Heavy reliance on hagwons adds cost and pressure.
Parental leave and child allowances exist but uptake low for fathers.
Some benefits extend to residents yet bureaucracy can limit use.
Top universities like Seoul National offer world-class programs.
Many universities have English tracks and scholarships for internationals.
Traditional expectations persist though younger generations push change.
Nonbinary identities receive limited recognition outside activist circles.
Legal equality but wage gap and glass ceiling remain issues.
Strong beauty culture and modesty expectations.
Professional success and military service shape male roles.
Blend of cutting-edge tech, pop culture, and ancient heritage.
English signage helps in Seoul, yet bureaucracy and social circles still rely on Korean.
Younger voters push progressive reforms, but national politics remain centrist-conservative on many issues.
Cold War legacy fosters skepticism toward Marxism.
About half the population identifies with no religion.
Public discourse is modest; sex education improving slowly.
Pride events occur, yet there’s no legal recognition for same-sex or polyamorous families and stigma persists.
Tight-knit circles form around schools and workplaces; integration takes effort.
Strong national pride tied to rapid development and cultural exports.
Historical tensions with Japan and North Korea; pragmatic with China.

values.key: View of Them by Neighboring Countries
values.alignmentText: Respected for economic success yet viewed through security lens.
Seoul’s nightlife is vibrant with late-night dining and entertainment.
Streetwear and grooming-focused styles set regional trends.
K-fashion blends modesty with cutting-edge looks.
Hiking, gaming, and cafe socializing are popular.
Board-game cafes and PC bangs support a growing tabletop scene.
K-pop concerts and clubs provide abundant music venues.
Expat and tech meetups occur regularly in Seoul.
Mountains and rivers are reachable even from major cities.
A robust democracy with competitive elections and independent courts, despite polarization.
Religious groups exert limited direct influence on policy.
Labor laws exist but enforcement against overwork is weak.
Liberal democracy paired with strong anti-communist stance.
Institutions are strong, though national security laws and surveillance powers merit monitoring.
Market economy dominated by chaebols yet entrepreneurial scene growing.
Domestic stability high but North Korea remains a security concern.
Media is largely free though national security messages are common.
Emphasis on anti-North sentiment and national unity.
Universal healthcare and expanding childcare subsidies help, but social safety nets still lag Nordic peers.
Trust swings with political scandals; citizens often rely on civic activism to push reforms.
Transparency scores are mid-to-high, though chaebol influence prompts periodic investigations.
Elite favoritism and corporate collusion surface more than street-level bribery.
Seoul’s jeonse deposits and condo prices are high, demanding significant savings.
Violent crime is rare; late-night transit feels safe for the kids and adults alike.
National Health Insurance offers fast access to quality hospitals and specialists.
Most long-term visas can join NHI, though initial enrollment requires paperwork in Korean.
Government stipends and public daycare slots are expanding, yet hours can be shorter than US standards.
Support improving yet not as generous as Nordic models.
Public schools deliver excellent academics, albeit with intense exam culture that may stress the kids.
Extensive subways, KTX high-speed rail, and cashless fare systems enable car-free living.
A market economy led by chaebol conglomerates balances innovation with regulatory oversight.
E-filing is streamlined, and year-end settlements auto-populate many deductions.
Combined income around ₩150M incurs marginal rates near 24% plus pension and health contributions.
Contactless payments and fast bank transfers are ubiquitous, though some apps require Korean ID verification.
Groceries and transit are affordable, but housing, education, and imported goods can be costly.
National Pension Service provides modest old-age benefits.
Foreign workers contribute and may reclaim pension when leaving.
Points-based F-2 residence and D-8 startup visas exist, yet they demand language, income, or investment proof.
Koreans are generally friendly, though social integration hinges on learning Korean and respecting norms.
Most visas renew yearly initially, with longer F-series options after meeting residence and language criteria.
Naturalization requires five years, TOPIK level 4, and renouncing prior citizenship unless special cases apply.
Spouses and children can join on dependent visas once the main applicant meets income and housing standards.
Immigration offices process applications in 2–4 months with moderate legal and translation fees.
Maintaining address registration, visa-specific employment, and health insurance is essential to avoid fines.
Generally not allowed except in rare talent or marriage cases.
Expect mandatory national pension contributions and periodic document checks, but services are reliable.
Major studios like Nexon, NCSoft, and Pearl Abyss actively hire and partner globally.

As noted in Game Dev Work Prospects, Major studios like Nexon, NCSoft, and Pearl Abyss actively hire and partner globally. Hiring velocity at established studios in South Korea wraps searches within a month or two as pipelines stay active.

Compensation remains competitive with other major hubs, mixing solid base pay and performance bonuses. When opportunities surface in South Korea, established studios benchmark offers against peers across the ecosystem.
Established studios in South Korea rely on English for cross-border collaboration, while local-language fluency remains important for community, compliance, and platform partnerships.
Remote expectations at established studios in South Korea are flexible for senior roles, with hybrid schedules common.
Seoul houses Nexon, NCSoft, Smilegate, and Krafton with sizable dev teams.
KR G-Star, Seoul Indies, and campus clubs provide strong networking and mentorship.
Government grants and accelerator programs exist, though competition and labor costs are high.

Startup founders report that Government grants and accelerator programs exist, though competition and labor costs are high. Hiring velocity at early-stage studios in South Korea is moderate, with teams needing a few months to land the right hire.
Compensation clusters around global medians, requiring negotiation to balance cost of living. Early teams in South Korea balance cash and equity to stay competitive while managing runway.
Founding teams in South Korea lean on English for investor and platform communication, while local-language fluency helps with hiring, compliance, and community outreach.
Remote expectations among startups in South Korea are mixed—teams juggle on-site collaboration with hybrid arrangements when possible.
Gigabit internet, efficient transit, and smart-city services make daily life highly connected.
Seasons are defined by severe volatility with repeated power outages, transportation pauses, or property damage concerns.
Months of oppressive darkness or bright nights disrupt sleep cycles and make remote work or study harder to sustain.
Only brief shoulder weeks feel good; most months push us indoors due to muggy, icy, or stormy conditions.
High living costs erode quality of life; reliable childcare or healthcare coverage often falls through the cracks.
We feel squeezed: decent neighborhoods or schools require long commutes or high costs that crowd out enrichment.
Luxury services are thin; wealth management and elite schooling often require another city.

values.key: Spacious Housing Benchmark (2k sq ft Rent)
values.alignmentText: Only a handful of listings surface each year; expect bidding wars and significant trade-offs.
Only experimental or short-term arrangements pop up, offering little stability for families.
Surface politeness exists yet deeper support systems take sustained effort to unlock.
Acceptance varies widely; caution is needed when discussing background in public spaces.
Suspicion around privilege is common, demanding constant humility and proof of local investment.
Interactions can be efficient yet emotionally flat; kindness takes effort to elicit.
Social circles are slow to open; we need persistence and shared projects to connect deeply.
Touchy or crowded norms are common and require constant boundary setting.
Honesty is situational; locals may avoid uncomfortable topics entirely.
We feel a gentle push to stay polished in professional or social spaces.
Visible pressure to stay slim or athletic influences work and school culture.
Certain districts expect polished outfits, though flexibility exists in family spaces.
Consent education is weak; unwanted advances occur regularly.
Rigid gender expectations create discomfort for progressive or queer expressions.
Negative narratives dominate; openness threatens custody, employment, or housing. non-monogamy acceptance.
Reputational risks exist, especially for women or queer folks discussing partners.
Disclosure triggers backlash or official scrutiny.
Culture favors close contact; sensory-sensitive family members often feel overwhelmed.
Guns are present yet culturally treated as tools with strong safety expectations.
Enforcement leans punitive; we monitor rules closely to avoid harsh consequences.
Street-level policing is visible; marginalized communities report frequent stops.
Recent history shows sporadic mass violence, so we stay vigilant at large gatherings.
Overcrowding or low wages appear in investigative reports, raising ethical concerns.
Sidewalks cover key areas but drivers often rush, so we stay alert with children.
Healthy living requires self-direction; fast food and sedentary habits dominate social life.
Ultra-processed options crowd shelves; schools and events lean heavily on packaged snacks.
We can meet most cravings but specialty ingredients or restaurants appear sporadically.
Prevalence is high with long waits and patchy insurance coverage.
Obesity is widespread, signaling systemic lifestyle challenges we must counter individually.
Slightly elevated incidence prompts routine checkups and monitoring.
Recessions hit noticeable segments, requiring flexibility or retraining.
